content.text: Overview of Other Rickettsial Spotted Fevers

This document provides an overview of less common rickettsial diseases that belong to the spotted fever group (SFG). These diseases are caused by various species of Rickettsia and are transmitted by ticks. They share clinical features with Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever (RMSF) but have distinct epidemiological characteristics.

items: An inoculation eschar (tache noire) at the site of the tick bite is a characteristic finding in many of these diseases, especially Mediterranean spotted fever.

content.text: Diagnosis is primarily based on clinical suspicion and epidemiological context. Serological tests, such as indirect immunofluorescence assay (IFA), are the mainstay of laboratory diagnosis. PCR of blood or skin biopsy samples can also be used for early diagnosis.

appliesTo.description: Adults and children with suspected or confirmed other rickettsial spotted fevers

durationDetail.fixedDuration: 7-14 days, or until the patient is afebrile for at least 3 days

regimenData.notes: Treatment should be initiated based on clinical suspicion and should not be delayed pending laboratory confirmation.
Chloramphenicol is an alternative but is associated with a higher mortality rate and potential toxicity. Its use should be carefully considered.
